fields.description:
h3. Feature Request

When clicking on the Releases tab, a number of columns display to provide basic information about releases. 

Often this data is not enough to plan, and clicking through to Jira is laborious. It would help with my planning if more information was exposed easier on the Releases interface, such as:
 * Version description
 * Version release notes

 

Sample:

!image-2021-02-03-09-19-22-449.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: As a ARJ user, having more information about releases would help my planning

We would also need the possibility of having the description visible on the plan in the highlighted space.
  !image-2021-02-02-16-38-05-767.png|width=302,height=80!

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When an ARJ Team is deleted, the record that ties that team to an issue is not removed from the database. Due to this, references to the deleted team can still be found in the issue, primarily by fetching data through the {{https://JIRA-BASE-URL/rest/api/2/issue/ISSUE-ID/properties/jpo-issue-properties}} endpoint.

In addition to this, no entries are added in the change history of the issue mentioning that the Team is no longer linked to that issue.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a shared team in ARJ.
# Edit any issue and add the new team using the *Team* field.
# Navigate back to the *Teams* page and delete the newly created team.

h3. Expected Results
Once the team has been deleted, the issue will no longer have any references to the deleted team. We would also see an entry in the change history of the issue indicating that the value for the team field has changed to null.

h3. Actual Results
You can still get references to the deleted team when fetching data from the following API endpoint: {{https://JIRA-BASE-URL/rest/api/2/issue/ISSUE-ID/properties/jpo-issue-properties}}

Also, not entries are logged in the issue's changed history - potentially, this is due to the fact that the entry in the database that links a team to an issue is not removed upon the team's deletion.

h3. Workaround
Currently, there is no workaround for this behavior. You are able to select a new team using the *Team* field as expected, but if no new team is selected, the value will be kept.
fields.summary: Deleting an ARJ team should remove references to this team made from Issues

fields.description: h3. Issue Summary HTML description not rendered for Advanced Roadmaps locked custom fields (Parent Link, Target Start, Target End). h3. Steps to Reproduce # Unlock one of the Advanced Roadmap custom fields by following [Unlock a custom field|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jirakb/unlock-a-locked-jira-software-custom-field-779158866.html]. For example *Parent Link* # In a project configuration edit the *field configuration scheme* and *edit the Parent Link* custom field to add a description to the field to be rendered in screens. # Insert an HTML description. For example: {code:java} Golden Field - Choose a parent to assign this issue to. {code} !Screenshot 2021-01-21 at 14.06.15.png|thumbnail! # Go to *Administration > System > General configuration* and toggle the HTML flag for custom field description to *ON*: !Screenshot 2020-11-24 at 5.15.03 PM.png|thumbnail! # Navigate to *Administration » Manage Add-ons*, filter the visible add-ons by System Add-ons and search for "wiki", to find the *Wiki Renderer Macros Plugin*. Make sure it it enabled. # Add the Parent Link field to the *Create issue screen* for the project. # Create an issue and observe that the HTML is not rendered: !Screenshot 2021-01-21 at 13.46.09.png|thumbnail! *Note 1:* Same happen with other locked Advanced Roadmap fields such as *Target Start and Target End.* *Note 2*: For other locked field such the Agile ones (ex. Epic link) by doing same as above HTML is rendered: !Screenshot 2021-01-21 at 14.17.50.png|thumbnail! *Note 3*: From Jira 8.7.0, the default behavior of the Enable HTML in custom field descriptions and list values items option has been changed so it is switched to OFF for new Jira installations and the upgraded ones that have never used it. However for my test I set it on and same is with Jira 8.5.0 in combination with the affected Advanced Roadmap versions. h3. Expected Results Given the changes made locked Advanced Roadmap custom fields HTML description should be rendered. h3. Actual Results Advanced Roadmap custom fields HTML description are not rendered. h3. Workaround Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: HTML description not rendered for Advanced Roadmaps locked custom fields

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The [Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1221237/advanced-roadmaps-for-jira-in-confluence?hosting=server&tab=overview] fails to load the plan when [sharing a plan|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapscloud/sharing-and-exporting-plan-data-998651329.html] from a Jira Software Cloud instance.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Follow the steps in [sharing a plan|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapscloud/sharing-and-exporting-plan-data-998651329.html] to create a Confluence sharing link for an Advanced Roadmaps plan on a Jira Software Cloud instance.

Save this link in the URL field of the [Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/apps/1221237/advanced-roadmaps-for-jira-in-confluence?hosting=server&tab=overview] macro.
h3. Expected Results

The Advanced Roadmaps plan will be shown on the Confluence page.
h3. Actual Results

Plan fails to display in the Advanced Roadmaps macro iframe.
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence macro fails to load a plan from Jira Software Cloud

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Indexing will break in version 3.29.2 and later if the Team custom field was ever renamed.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Upgrade or install Advanced roadmaps to 3.29.2
# Rename Team custom field.
# Perform any action that trigger indexing.
#* such as: Creating/Editing/Transitioning issue that has value for Team custom field

h3. Expected Results
Action is successful. Issue index is updated

h3. Actual Results
Action proceeds but issue index is not updated. 
The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-jira.log file:
{noformat}
2020-12-13 19:21:15,186+0000 https-jsse-nio-8443-exec-166 WARN XXXXX XXXXxXXXXXxX XXXXXXX XXX.XXX.XXX.XX,XX.XX.XXX.XX /secure/WorkflowUIDispatcher.jspa [c.a.jira.index.AccumulatingResultBuilder] java.lang.IllegalStateException: Team custom field ID cannot be found
java.lang.RuntimeException: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Team custom field ID cannot be found
	at com.atlassian.jira.index.DefaultIndex$Failure.<init>(DefaultIndex.java:100)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIssueIndexer$EntityOperation.perform(DefaultIssueIndexer.java:838)
	at com.atlassian.jira.issue.index.DefaultIssueIndexer.lambda$null$4(DefaultIssueIndexer.java:513)
...
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalStateException: Team custom field ID cannot be found
	at com.atlassian.rm.teams.customfields.team.TeamCustomFieldTypeHelper.getCustomFieldId(TeamCustomFieldTypeHelper.java:74)
	at com.atlassian.rm.teams.customfields.team.TeamCustomFieldType.getCustomFieldId(TeamCustomFieldType.java:44)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround
Rename the team field back to its initial name *Team*.

(i) Renaming issue fields would affect the saved filters that refers them in JQL. Make sure to update the JQL of those saved filters as well. Reference: [Indexing breaks after upgrading to Advanced Roadmaps to Jira 3.29.2 when Team field was renamed|https://confluence.atlassian.com/roadmaps-kb/indexing-breaks-after-upgrading-to-advanced-roadmaps-to-jira-3-29-2-when-team-field-was-renamed-1041827901.html].
fields.summary: Renaming Team custom field breaks index

fields.description:
While viewing information associated with programs, it would be nice if Advanced Roadmaps Administrators had the ability to include certain issue types that belong to lower hierarchical levels than *Epic*.

Even though programs provide you with a macro view of your roadmap, it would certainly provide additional business value if users were able to customize the program to include these issue types and see how their information would interact with Epics and Initiatives.
fields.summary: Allow Advanced Roadmaps Administrators to include information associated with different issue types to programs

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In ARJ 3.29.2, in order for ARJ custom field to be included in Jira's indexing improvement, ARJ is referring to its fields by name. If customer has ever renamed the Team custom field, they may hit into this issue:
* [Indexing breaks after upgrading to Advanced Roadmaps to Jira 3.29.2 when Team field was renamed|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/PORTFOLIOKB/Indexing+breaks+after+upgrading+to+Advanced+Roadmaps+to+Jira+3.29.2+when+Team+field+was+renamed]

h3. Suggested Solution
As a preventive measure, Advanced Roadmaps for Jira 3.29.2 Release note should include the following warning:
{quote}
(i) If at any point of time, Advanced Roadmaps for Jira *Team* custom field was renamed, please ensure that the change has been reverted prior to upgrading to version 3.29.2. 

Known issue:
* [Indexing breaks after upgrading to Advanced Roadmaps to Jira 3.29.2 when Team field was renamed|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/PORTFOLIOKB/Indexing+breaks+after+upgrading+to+Advanced+Roadmaps+to+Jira+3.29.2+when+Team+field+was+renamed]
{quote}
fields.summary: Updating Advanced Roadmaps for Jira 3.29.2 release note to include a note on ARJ custom field name dependency

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When using the [auto-schedule|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapsserver/auto-scheduling-issues-967895245.html] feature in Advanced Roadmaps, if a Plan contain multiple Teams associated to the same issue source, the auto-scheduling will fail with no warnings at the UI and a NullPointerException in the application logs.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a Plan
# Create multiple Teams at the same Plan
# Associate the Teams to the same issue source
# Use {{Auto-schedule}}

h3. Expected Results
Advanced Roadmaps will schedule the issues in the Plan successfully.

h3. Actual Results
Advanced Roadmaps will not schedule the issues without any warnings, and will throw the following exception at the application logs:
{noformat}
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.scheduling.roadmap.scheduling.algo.construct.common.MutableResourceGroup.schedule(MutableResourceGroup.java:135)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.scheduling.roadmap.scheduling.algo.construct.GreedyRoadmapScheduler.updateResources(GreedyRoadmapScheduler.java:245)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.scheduling.roadmap.scheduling.algo.construct.GreedyRoadmapScheduler.handleFixedSlotProblem(GreedyRoadmapScheduler.java:239)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.scheduling.roadmap.scheduling.algo.construct.GreedyRoadmapScheduler.schedule(GreedyRoadmapScheduler.java:100)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.scheduling.roadmap.scheduling.solver.GreedyRoadmapPlanningSolver.solveRoadmapPlanningProblem(GreedyRoadmapPlanningSolver.java:45)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.calc.NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.getRoadmapScheduleInternal(NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.java:156)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.calc.NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.getRoadmapSchedule(NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.java:118)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.calc.NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.getSchedulingSolution(NonPersistingSchedulingSolutionService.java:74)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.scheduling.jobs.CalculationJob.run(CalculationJob.java:51)
	at com.atlassian.rm.jpo.env.threading.JiraLongRunningExecutorRegistry$1$1.run(JiraLongRunningExecutorRegistry.java:48)
	at com.atlassian.rm.common.bridges.jira.threading.LongRunningExecutorServiceBridge710.lambda$execute$0(LongRunningExecutorServiceBridge710.java:104)
	at com.atlassian.rm.common.bridges.jira.threading.JiraSafeThreadService.lambda$execute$0(JiraSafeThreadService.java:47)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:266)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1149)
	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:624)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:748)
{noformat}

h3. Workaround

* Having both teams set to 'None' fixes the problem. 
* Having one team set to 'None' and the other one set to a specific issue source works without exception, but only schedules part of the issues.
fields.summary: Auto-scheduling issues with multiple teams associated to the same issue source fails with no warnings at the UI

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Whenever you create multiple contexts for a custom field that are applied to different projects if you create a plan selecting only one of these projects as an issue source, Advanced Roadmaps for Jira will display all of the custom field options available for the field, regardless of the context associated with the project.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a *Select List (single choice)* custom field.
 # Configure multiple contexts for this custom field, as in the screenshot below:
 !Screen Shot 2021-01-11 at 18.20.40.png|thumbnail! 
 # Add the created custom field to your plan (*Cog Icon* > *Configure* > *Custom Fields* > *Add custom field* > Select the correct custom field and click on *Add 1 field*).
 # Navigate back to the plan, insert a value for the custom field in one of the issues (you will notice that the context is respected).
 !Screen Shot 2021-01-11 at 18.53.47.png|thumbnail! 
 # Click on the *Filters* button, locate the custom field inserted and click on the dropdown menu associated with it. 

h3. Expected Results

* Only the options associated with the context being used will be displayed.

h3. Actual Results

* All custom field options are displayed. Additionally, if multiple contexts display the same option, they will all be listed, but users will not be able to differentiate them.

 !Screen Shot 2021-01-11 at 18.54.11.png|thumbnail! 
h3. Workaround

* Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior other than using independent custom fields instead of multiple contexts in a single one. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: Plan filters include custom field options that are not relevant to the plan's sources context

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
When editing the Issue Source from any Plan, the ‘Issues Without Parent Epics’ checkbox will be always ticked, even if you uncheck it and saved this configuration.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create or Edit a Plan 
# Go to the “Confirm what’s in scope” section 
# Uncheck the ‘Issues Without Parent Epics’ box.
# Save
# Go back to edit the Issue Source once again and you'll see the 'Issues Without Parent Epics’ box ticked.

h3. Expected Results
'Issues Without Parent Epics’ box is unchecked

h3. Actual Results
'Issues Without Parent Epics’ box is ticked

h3. Workaround
fields.summary: ‘Issues Without Parent Epics’ checkbox is always ticked in “Confirm what’s in scope” section

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
*NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Server*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOCLOUD-1671].
{panel}
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, there is an upper limit of 50 teams, 100 Projects and 5000 open issues per plan due to performance restriction. 

!image-2016-10-14-14-16-33-277.png!

 
h3. Suggested Solution

We want to make this more scalable and allowing more project and issues per plan to support larger clients.
h3. Workaround

None.

 
{panel:title=Atlassian Update - 7 January 2018}
Hi All,

Thank you for commenting on this issue with your feedback. I’d like to give you a quick update on this feature improvement. We’re continuously investigating solutions to improve performance, but loading & viewing a very large amount of issues at once is complex. 

The issue & project limits most likely won't be extended in the next few months. The Reason is that we chose to invest most of our effort in simplifying the UI with a brand new design, details can be found [here|https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Portfolio-for-Jira-articles/Introducing-a-new-planning-experience-in-Portfolio-for-Jira/ba-p/944996]. 

We know that this is a major issue for some of you and longer term ( 12-18 months ) we will  increase our efforts to extend these limits in a way that won’t lower performance.

In the meantime, I would advise customers to split their work streams into different plans. You could use the [Programs feature|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/programs-931037964.html] to get an aggregated view of multiple plans, for basic reporting functionality.  

Roi Fine | Product Manager 
{panel}
fields.summary: Increase the project, issue, and team limits in Plan

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The newly added Sub-task issue type is not showing in the Issue Type dropdown on the "Create Issue" screen while creating a sub-task through an Advanced Roadmap Plan. The issue Type field is greyed out.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 - Add a new Sub-Task Issue Type (say Risk Management)
 - Add this to an Issue Type Scheme which is associated with a project.
 - Make some of the Jira fields like Description/Component a mandatory field.
 - Go to an Advanced Roadmap Project Plan and try to create a sub-task within a task/story
 - Click on Review changes and Save selected changes in Jira.
 - The issue Type field is greyed out and no option to select the newly added Sub-Task Issue type on the Set required field screen of create issue :
 !Screenshot 2021-01-06 at 6.20.58 PM.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow newly added sub-task issue type to be selected while creating a sub-task through a plan.
h3. Workaround

Disable improved interface and click on Uncommitted changes. Select the uncommitted sub-task and the newly added Issue-type can be selected. Sub-task can be created successfully and visible on the plan. Enable Improved interface again.
 !Screenshot 2021-01-06 at 6.32.12 PM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: The newly added Sub-task issue type is not showing in the Issue Type dropdown

fields.description: A Roadmap allows you to set a custom time range to view that's either a fixed time range or relative to when you're viewing it (ex. Last 3 months). You don't get that option with a Program however, it seems to set the time range automatically based on the start/end dates of the issues in the Roadmaps it's showing. It would be nice if this were customizable
fields.summary: Allow custom time ranges for Programs

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Following up JPOSERVER-2534. Depending on the hierarchy levels for Advanced Roadmaps, this function can be expensive and impact the performance of anything that uses JQL, such as WebHooks. 

h3. Suggested Solution
Change the way issues are retrieved when using this function, allowing faster responses when Advanced Roadmaps is involved.
fields.summary: Improve the performance from the childIssuesOf JQL function
Aligning release dates - Article displaying incomplete information

This request comes back to us often from our clients who have already worked with MS Project
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmaps Automatically calculated

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Whenever a custom field created has the *Target End* custom field type, if you limit its context to a certain amount of projects and name this field with certain variations of the following words:
 * *Target*
 * *End*

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Click on the *Jira Administration Icon* > *Issues*.
# Select *Custom fields* at the sidebar.
# Click on *Add custom field*.
# Click on *Advanced*.
# Select *Target end*.
# Insert a *Name* and a *Description*, let's use it *Target* as an example (there are certain name variations that will cause this bug, such as *Target*, *End*, *Target End Date*, *Ending*. 
# Click on *Create*.
# Back into the *Custom fields* page, search for the field created using the search bar.
# Click on the *Cog* icon, under the *Actions* column, and select *Configure*.
# On the *Applicable* contexts for scheme, select *Edit configuration*.
# Scroll down until you locate the *Choose applicable context* section, select the *Apply to issues under selected projects* and select a project that has not been listed as an issue source in your Advanced Roadmaps plan (let's call it *Project X*).
# Click on the *Modify* button.
# Navigate to your Advanced Roadmaps plan that does not have *Project X* listed as an issue source.
# Update the value of the default *Target end* field in your plan.
# Click on the *Review changes* button and *Save selected changes in Jira*.

h3. Expected Results

The *Success* message is displayed, and the *Target end* value in the original field has been updated.

h3. Actual Results

The *Success* message is displayed but its value is not updated.

h3. Workaround

* Naming the custom field being created using words that do not stem from *Target* and *End* words (I have used *Test*, and it worked as expected).
* Not restricting the context of the newly created field.
fields.summary: Creating a Target End custom field and restricting its context to certain projets breaks the default Target End field under certain circumstances.

fields.description:
Currently when running the /rest/api/2/issue call, the Advanced Roadmaps (aka Portfolio) Team field value displays the ID for that team.

It would be great if we could display the Team name directly, like we have for other fields, like Select Fields or the Sprint field.
fields.summary: Add Advanced Roadmaps Team name to Issue rest call

fields.description:
In Advanced Roadmaps for Jira, parent-child relationships are managed through the *Parent Link* field. Once this relationship is established, it will be displayed through the parent issue's *Child issues* section.

Currently, the *Child issues* panel implemented by Advanced Roadmaps does not provide any features, being only a way to see the children of a certain issue.

It would be nice if the panel's functionalities could be extended to allow users to manage children (i.e. include new issues as children, or remove children that are currently listed on that section) through that section.
fields.summary: Extend the functionality of the Child issues panel allowing users to manage Parent-Child relationships

fields.description:
h3. Description

In addition to this, if I currently change a configuration like removing the Scheduled Start and Scheduled End columns of my view and share the program, the next person will open the program and the edited columns will be there.
fields.summary: Add more flexibility to edit the shared Program view

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, when defining the scope of a Plan, sub-tasks will not be included on it  unless their parent issues are in its scope. 

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow users to include sub-tasks on a Plan, even if their parent issues are not on its scope.
fields.summary: Allow sub-tasks to be included in a Plan if its parent is not part of it

fields.description: Right now when for example assigning users, Advanced Roadmaps will show the full list of assignable users in the entire instance, it will not respect the assignable user permission on a project until the change is committed. Some companies have a "tenant" based system, this means they don't necessarily want one client seeing the usernames of another, even if they can't assign them something. Adding this feature will also restrict what issue sources a user can setup based on permissions.
fields.summary: Advanced Road Maps should respect Project level permissions

fields.description:

 # Click on release tab to observe the release level details

h3. Actual Results
 !Screen Shot 2020-11-19 at 4.10.05 pm.png|thumbnail! 

Issue count shows the issue count as hours, which is wrong

 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Using Jira Portfolio JQL function, namely issuesInPlan, issuesInProgram, childIssuesOf, can cause the thread to stall while Jira Portfolio calculates custom field for plan data.

This is because the JPOS function, {{DefaultPlanCustomFieldService#getRelevantCustomFieldIds}} obtains the data inefficiently by running N+1 SELECT query against the database. First query retrieve a list of plan IDs (from {{AO_D9132D_PLAN}}) and then for each plan ID another query runs against {{AO_D9132D_PLAN_CUSTOM_FIELD}} to retrieve a list of the custom fields linked to that plan.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create 1000 Portfolio plans, some with assigned custom fields
 # Add a filter with JQL function above
 # Try to load the filter, use it in a board or Filter Issues gadget.

h3. Expected Results

The function of Jira loads relitively quickly
h3. Actual Results
 * The thread takes a long time to complete
 * When view AWR report, high number of SELECT query to {{AO_D9132D_PLAN_CUSTOM_FIELD}}
 * Long running thread on database on *com.atlassian.rm.jpo.core.plancustomfield.DefaultPlanCustomFieldService.getCustomFieldIdsForPlan -* for example:
{code:java}
"http-nio-8080-exec-119 url:/rest/gadget/1.0/favfilters username:mars" #11506 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f59b00ff000 nid=0x254a runnable [0x00

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Whenever a plan's loading limits are violated Advanced Roadmaps for Jira may include unselected issues, even when a subset of issues that is lesser than the loading limit violated is selected.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an Advanced Roadmaps for Jira plan that violates one of the [loading limits|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapsserver/working-with-plans-952623578.html].
 # Configure the plan's scope to include only a subset of the plan that includes lesser issues and does not violate the limit.

h3. Expected Results
* Only the selected issues will be included in the plan scope.

h3. Actual Results
* Additional unselected issues appear on the plan scope.

h3. Workaround
* Remove issues using *Bulk actions*.
* On the plan scope, select all issues that must be removed.
* Under the hierarchy section, on the scope panel, you should see the *Bulk actions* dropdown menu, click on it and select *Remove from plan*.
fields.summary: Plan scope includes unselected issues if loading limits are violated

fields.description: It would be useful if we could modify a dependency instead of having to delete and recreate it.  Mainly to modify the dependency type if needed but also to potentially change which ticket the dependency relates to (less of an issue).
fields.summary: Ability to Modify Dependencies

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When converting an issue like an Epic to an Intiative, when it is already Parent Linked to an Intiative, the system does not automatically let go of the existing Parent link. It should do so since you cannot Parent link two issues at the top of the hierarchical levels, such as Initiative to Initiative.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Link and Initiative to an Epic
 # Convert the Epic into an Initiative
 # Observe the issues are still linked

h3. Expected Results

Newly converted initiative would not still be Parent linked to another Initative.
h3. Actual Results

The Initiatives are still Parent Linked together, showing a yellow exclamation warning. The warning is good, but this shouldn't be happening at all.
h3. Workaround

Convert the issue back to its previous issue type, remove the link, and convert the issue back to an initiative.
fields.summary: Converting an issue's type to the same level as its Parent does not relinquish its existing Parent link as it should.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Making all plans private in advanced road maps causes performance issue

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Advanced road map plugin
 # Make all the plan private. 
 # Try to make a call to following API's 
{code}
/rest/teams-api/latest/team
/rest/jpo/1.0/programs/list
{code}
It takes more then 30 seconds to load the page.


h3. Expected Results
The calls to program list or team should not take 30 seconds to load the page.

h3. Actual Results

We see the frequent calls for permission checks in database logs.
{code}
sum(case when ("pp"."PROGRAM_ID" = $1 and "pp"."PERMISSION" = $2) then cast($3 as int4) else cast($4 as int4) end)
{code}

h3. Workaround
If the plans are not restricted as private the issue does not occur. To avoid this issue, we need to make the plans public.
fields.summary: Making all plans private has an impact on performance

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Capacity distribution algorithm doesn't pay attention to mid-week dates

In the new capacity distribution algorithm (scrum + kanban), we don't consider the start date of an issue other than to bucket the issue into a sprint/iteration.

We assume all issues that start in an iteration start on the first day.
 See how moving this issue through the week - even starting it on the weekend - has no effect on the capacity.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a new Epic
 # Create a new Story and set the "Original Estimate" and "Remaining Estimate" to 40h
 # Link the new Story to the Epic created
 # Navigate to the plan
 # Go to the "Teams" tab
 # Create a new team with the settings below:
 -- Team type: Kanban
 -- Capacity (weekly hours): 40
 # Set the Story created to:
 -- 
 --- Estimates: 40
 -- Team: select the team created above
 -- Target start: 10/Dec/2020
 -- Target end: 16/Dec/2020
 # Check the capacity insights
 !capacity_AR.png|thumbnail!

h3. Expected Results

Capacity should consider the start date and calculate the capacity accordingly.
h3. Actual Results

Capacity distribution algorithm doesn't pay attention to mid-week dates
h3. Workaround

Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Capacity distribution algorithm doesn't pay attention to mid-week dates

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently the *Estimate* field in Portfolio corresponds to the *Remaining Estimate* in JIRA issue

h3. Suggested Solution
Rename the Estimate field in Portfolio to Remaining Estimate
fields.summary: Rename the Estimate field in Portfolio to Remaining Estimate

fields.description: Similar to the way that you can displa a Plan roadmap with Advance Roadmaps for Jira in Confluence
fields.summary: Add a gadget to display the Program Roadmap on a Confluence page

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When turning on roll-up for estimates in an AR plan, the roll up calculates the estimate and roll-up values against the parent. 

!image-2020-11-05-07-59-15-273.png|width=864,height=194!
h3. In above screenshot; 

Epic:
 * IOS-20 has 10 rolled up story points from stories and an estimate of 30 points against it. 
 * ARD-16 has 40 points estimated

Initiative: PM-2 has rolled up story points value of 80. This is (10 + 30 + 40). We are doubling up on the estimate and roll up value from IOS-20. 
h3. Expected Results
 # Option to have the story points value rolled up at only the story level to get an accurate representation of work estimated against the epic/initiative level. (preferred). 
 # OR the story point roll up should be excluded automatically (calculation that removes from the estimate)  

h3. Actual Results
{noformat}
Currently we are doubling up on the estimates as it calculates both the estimate field and the rolled up estimate when rolling up to parent. 
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Manually update the parent estimate to remove the values equivalent to the roll up or turn off roll up values feature.
fields.summary: Roll-Up should only include story points from story level issues

fields.description:
As a Jira Administrator, it would be nice if an Epic's progress was color-coded according to a comparison between the epic's current progress and the scheduling generated by Advanced Roadmaps, for instance:

Blue: EPIC complete.
Green: EPIC on track to complete as forecast.
Amber: EPIC has deviated from the target completion date, remediation is realistic and can be applied.
Red: EPIC has deviated from the target completion date, remediation will not support EPIC being completed on time.

The colors could be changed in other to not conflict with other visual clues currently used in Advanced Roadmaps.
fields.summary: Introduce color-coded visual clues to inform if Epics progress is on track.

fields.description: Wherever I am viewing a bunch of issues I'd like they can be sort using the same order that shows in the plan
fields.summary: Option to use "plan order" to sort issues all arround

fields.description: Currently, it is not possible to include the *Reporter* field in an Advanced Roadmaps plan, as a Jira Administrator, we would like to be able to do so.
fields.summary: Ability to include the Reporter field in a plan.

fields.description:
Currently we only support following types of custom fields : 


*     checkbox
*     date picker
*     user picker (single user)
*     number
*     radio button
*     label
*     single-choice select
*     multiple-choice select
*     single-line text
*     URL (read-only)


While integrating Insight Asset Mangement, it offers different types of custom fields which are not yet supported by Advanced Roadmaps 
 !Screenshot 2020-10-30 at 13.30.51.png|thumbnail! 


These fields are greyed out when selecting them into the plan 
 !Screenshot 2020-10-30 at 13.43.51.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Support for the Insight Custom fields

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Time difference 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set the local OS time different then the server time
# Create a new program 
# Sync the program 
# You will notice the time difference as below

h3. Expected Results
Time difference should not be there. It should show the actual time

h3. Actual Results
Time difference is observed. Screenshot below: 

 !program_sync_issue.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Sync time shows difference in program

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When adding the Advanced Roadmap field *Parent Link* to the *Fields* of a Jira Service Desk *Request Type*, the field is addable to "Hidden fields with preset values". However, when attempting to set a preset value, the dropdown Issue Picker does not show, and a preset value is therefore not selectable.
h3. Environment

Tested in two environments, with same workflow and end result:
 * Jira Software+Core 7.13.2 , Jira Service Desk 3.16.2, Jira Portfolio 3.1.0
 * Jira Software+Core 8.1.0, Jira Service Desk 4.1.0, Jira Portfolio 3.1.0

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Jira Admin -> Addons -> Portfolio Hierarchy Configuration -> Add top level - Name="Initiative", Jira Issue Types = Task
 # Create a new Sample Software project, type Scrum
 # Jira Admin -> Issues -> Screens.
 ## Find "Scrum Default Issue Screen" for the new project -> *Configure*
 ## Add "Parent Link" field to the screen configuration
 # Go back to the created project, enter *Project Settings*
 ## Under Details, Change the Project to type Service Desk
 ## Request Types -> Create a new Request Type, Issue Type=Epic
 ## Click *Add a Field* -> Select "Parent Link" -> *Apply*
 ## The field appears in "hidden fields with preset values". Under parent link click Edit Value
 ## (*r) +*The dropdown issue picker does not display*+

h3. Expected Results
 * The dropdown issue picker displays, and allows a preset Jira Issue to be selected

h3. Actual Results
 * The dropdown issue picker does not display

h3. Notes

The field defined in the steps above can be verified to work correctly in Jira Issue Screen  -
 # In Jira, Create a new Issue of type *Epic*
 #Under *Parent Link*, observe that the dropdown issue picker correctly shows, and shows Jira Issues of type Task

The Issue Type "Epic" was used in the example above, but it not need to that to reproduce the issue. It just has to satisfy the requirements of the Parent Link field.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available. 
 The Parent Link field will need to be edited in another way (for instance, a bulk edit in Jira, or via the Jira Portfolio interface)
fields.summary: The field Parent Link cannot have a preset value assigned in a JSD Request Type

fields.description:
It looks like our [Managing your releases|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapsserver/managing-your-releases-968677249.html] documentation is not clear about the expected behavior regarding auto-scheduling releases.

While Advanced Roadmaps can project dates for releases, these are not populated and can just be viewed when auto-scheduling.

JPOSERVER-2881 was created to address this functionality, though perhaps we should be more clear that this information won't be persisted for now.
fields.summary: Update our Managing Releases documentation

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Currently, when using the auto-schedule feature from Advanced Roadmaps, it will display projected release dates based on our scheduling algorithm. With that said, after accepting the changes, the release dates are not populated anywhere, and cannot be seen unless auto-schedule is used again.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow users to populate this information on versions automatically, or at least display this information without using auto-schedule.
fields.summary: Allow users to populate release dates for versions based on auto-schedule
"Select this and all descendant issues" option also selects issues not in view

fields.description: As a Jira Administrator, it would be nice if we could select certain fields and make them read-only to prevent edition from users accessing our Advanced Roadmaps for Jira plans.
fields.summary: Introduce the ability to make specific fields read-only.

fields.description:
ARJ places this extra condition when loading a plan based on the plan config to exclude completed issues - but does not apply it for the issuesInPlan JQL function.

This impacts the performance for large enterprise instances since

- Jira Software boards by default does not exclude completed issues

- many teams do not have healthy backlogs.
fields.summary: issuesInPlan function should exclude completed issues similar to the behaviour in plans

fields.description: Depending on the search template being used by a custom field, Advanced Roadmaps is unable to include the custom field's data on its plans. Extending support to search templates implemented by 3rd-party applications would greatly boost Advanced Roadmaps for Jira's capabilities.
fields.summary: Extend support for 3rd-party application search templates

fields.description: Currently, users are only able to see the progress of an issue through the scope section, by using the *Progress (estimation unit)* or *Progress (Issue Count)* fields.  It would be nice if there was a numerical/percentage field representing the progress of that particular issue, that could receive manual input and display some sort of visual representation of the current progress on the schedule bar.
fields.summary: Include visual representation of the progress of an issue in the Schedule Bar

fields.description: Currently, it is not possible to translate Advanced Roadmaps for Jira to other languages, as there are certain regulations (such as the 101 Law in Québec) that require software to be translated, that could be a legal issue for some of our customers.
fields.summary: Introduce support to other languages in Advanced Roadmaps for Jira

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Provide the capability to allow a subset of users to view shared teams and a different subset to be able to manage them.

In the context of a large enterprise environment, administrators may want to separate these groups as they will not want all users who can view, to also be able to modify shared team members.
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behaviour.
fields.summary: Split out view and manage shared teams permissions

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When a user with no link issue permissions creates an issue and sets the parent link, the issue gets created and in the issue of the parent you can see the child issue, but in the issuelink table, there are no entries.

This doesn't seem to cause any problems in the behaviour with this missing data as it seems to be redundant data

However, we should either stop allowing the user to set the parent link or save the data in the same manner as a user with the link issue permissions.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

 
 * Create a custom issue type that is a level above epics

 * Create an issue of this new custom issue type

 * Login as a user that has access to create but not link issue permissions access

 * Create a epic and set the parent link to the previously created issue

h3. Expected Results

Either all data created correctly 
 or 
 The issue does not get saved with the parent link
h3. Actual Results

No entry in the issuelink table but we can see the child issue on the parent.
h3. Workaround

Resave the parent link as a user with link issue permissions
fields.summary: Inconsistent data when saving parent link with no link issue permissions

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Whenever you have a status that has a long name (~30 characters long), you will not be able to read its complete name. Instead, a partial representation of the name will be displayed with ellipsis being included.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a workflow status with a large name (>= 35 characters) and associate with the issue types of a project.
 # Create a plan using the mentioned project as a source.
 # Create an issue and transition it to the workflow status created in step 1.
 

h3. Expected Results
* You should have a way to display the status entire name.

h3. Actual Results
* Even after mousing-over the workflow status in the plan view or granting additional space to the *Status* field, the entire workflow name is not displayed.

h3. Workaround
 Currently, there is no known workaround for this behavior, other than using shorter names for a workflow status. A workaround will be added here when available.

 !Screen Shot 2020-10-15 at 14.41.27.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Long statuses names are not completely readable in Plan view.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If you disable options in the select list and checkbox custom fields the value cannot be selected from the issue but the option is still present in the field in the Plan view if you add the custom field as a column in your plan. 

Disabled options should not be able to be selected, but do remain on existing issues, and can still be searched and will show up in reports.

h3. Environment
* Tested on Advanced Roadmaps 3.29.2

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to admin > Issues > custom fields
# find or create a select list custom field 
# Under configuration select "Edit Options" to get to the list of options.  
# Note Next to each option, you have actions - delete, rename, and disable.
# Disable one of the options
# Add the Custom Field to your plan
# select the drop-down to choose an option from the plan view

h3. Expected Results
The Disabled option is not present, therefore it cannot be selected as a valid option

h3. Actual Results
The Disabled option is present and can be selected and added to new issues

h3.Workaround
No Workaround at this time
fields.summary: Select list and checkbox field options set to disabled are still visible in the Plan view

fields.description:
h3. Summary
As covered in [JPOSERVER-1847 | https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1847] the team field is a non-standard field type specific to Advanced roadmaps, and as a result, the Team value when added to a subtask is inherited from the parent issue it is associated with and will display the parent issue team value on the child subtask.  However when converting a sub-task to a standard issue type the team value is removed from the issue and no issue history change item is noted that the value was removed or that the value was previously set due to the place holder nature of the inherited value

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an issue
# Assign a team to the issue
# Create a subtask for that issue (Note the team field is populated with the same team as the parent automatically)
# On the subtask issue view screen
#* Select MORE > Convert to issue
#* Follow prompts to convert to a story
#* Note that the prompts at step 3 of 4 will either display "All fields will be updated automatically" OR will list fields that can have a value set, but does not note the Team Field as a configurable field option to change the existing value at this step in the conversion and step 4 of 4 confirmation of changes page also does not show the team field value will be removed.

h3. Expected Results
Either the change history item shows the field is cleared at step 4 indicating a new team needs to be selected, OR the team field is listed as a configurable field in step 3 of 4 to choose a new value for the field

h3. Actual Results
Field is cleared and no change history item noted on the issue history tabs

h3.Workaround
Either manually set a new team OR autoschedule to have a team calculated for the issue fter converting
fields.summary: Team field is not properly set after converting a sub-task to an issue

fields.description:
*Issue:*

It is not immediately clear that if you do not click out of the field, then the value is not taken.

This is compounded by the assumption the enter key would submit the data, when it actually does not.

*Request:*

Please allow the enter key to apply the data, add a save button, or apply a small blurb below the field indicating it is not saved until you click out of it.

!image-2020-10-08-14-35-48-007.png!

*Example:*
 In the screenshot above, if I click "Back to Plan" before clicking out of the field - the value is not saved and isn't immediately apparent or obvious what went wrong what happened.
fields.summary: Allow the enter key to apply change to "Complete Issues" setting in Plan Configuration.

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Provide the capability to allow a subset of users to create plans and a (possibly) different subset to edit them.

In the context of a large enterprise environment, administrators may want to restrict who can create plans because:
 * They may have a phased rollout and only want to grant users to the right to create plans once they are trained
 * They would prefer to restrict this ability in general so that only team of teams and above leaders can create these plans
 * They would like to control the number of plans being created

Currently the permission to be able to create plans is also tied to the permission to edit them, meaning there isn't a way to lock down the right to create plans and still allow users to be able to edit them and save changes to Jira. The "Advanced Roadmaps restricted user" role still allows the user to create plans but doesn't let them make changes back to Jira, so it doesn't fit this need.

In addition, being able to separate "delete" permissions from the general "edit" permissions is needed as well. It isn't ideal in most enterprise organisations for users who can edit portfolio plans to also be able to delete them (and anyone else's). 
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior apart from restricting membership of the AR "user" role to administrators who will manage the plan creation and AR "restricted user" role to trusted users with the understanding they won't create plans ( and possibly insert a hack to remove the option from the UI). 

There is no workaround for stopping users from being able to delete plans.
fields.summary: Separate Create, Edit and Delete permissions for plans

The customer planning based on target PI and Sprint within the PI (and releases). It isn't significant to pick a specific date.
 The customer is aiming to be able to set this up at the plugin administration level. These dates would then be used as the sprint boundaries for all plans (rather than, for example, a project having to create ALL 2-week sprints for their entire schedule upfront, which could be 2-3 years worth of sprints).

# Add a permission actor via /plan/establish endpoint, such as
{code}curl -X POST https://\{instanceUrl}/rest/jpo/1.0/permissions/plan/establish -d '{"permission":{"permission":"EDIT","holder":{"key":"JIRAUSER33200","type":"USER"}},"planId":10}' -u user:password -H 'Content-Type: application/json'{code}
# Run above command a few more times
# The permissions table now contains duplicate entries.

It should throw error or should not allow to enter duplicate values 

h3. Actual Results
The duplicate values are entered in the database 


h3. Workaround
 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Duplicate entry gets created while editing permission through REST API

    at https://gsep-int.daimler.com/jira/s/d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e-CDN/-iuj9c0/805004/e846fa577baa8cffccdfee72f3059ccb/3.29.1/_/download/batch/com.atlassian.jpo:jpo-wr-page-portfolio-frontend-vendor-scripts/com.atlassian.jpo:jpo-wr-page-portfolio-frontend-vendor-scripts.js:14:330282
    at https://gsep-int.daimler.com/jira/s/d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e-CDN/-iuj9c0/805004/e846fa577baa8cffccdfee72f3059ccb/3.29.1/_/download/batch/com.atlassian.jpo:jpo-wr-page-portfolio-frontend-vendor-scripts/com.atlassian.jpo:jpo-wr-page-portfolio-frontend-vendor-scripts.js:14:204705
{noformat}
h3. Steps to Reproduce
h4. Scenario 1:

(x) Unable to reproduce at our end.
 # Log into a plan as a user who is not the current or original assignee for any issue in the plan
 # Create or modify a Release, Cross-Project Release, or Team. Don't change any issues.
 # Review the changes (_Only the newly created release or with some other uncommitted changes from other users_)
 # Select "All" Changed by Filter

h4. Scenario 2

(/) Reproducible.
 # Login as UserA and make changes to a plan (do not commit changes)
 # Disable UserA in Jira User Management page
 # Login as UserB, open the same plan and click "Review Changes"
 # Select "All" Changed by Filter

h3. Expected Results

List the user ID's of those who has added/modified changes in the plan to choose only their changes to be reviewed before commit it.
h3. Actual Results

Clicking the Filter throws an Error as above.

(x) There is no error or exception in the Jira log.
h3. Workaround

(flag) For the “Changed by” filter, Jira populating the list of users using data from a piece of the frontend state called *“assigneeList”*. When the app first loads, this state is populated with users who have issues assigned to them.

In this case, there is a user who has made a change, who is not in the assigneeList and then the app tries to get their details (name, avatar etc.) from assigneeList, doesn’t find them, and crashes with the error as "Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property *'jiraUsername'* of undefined"

(on) A possible workaround is to temporarily assign an issue to whichever user made the change, which will cause them to be added to assigneeList and It will fix the problem. (If it’s known which user that is…)

Another way is, just opening the assignee selector for an issue might fix it as this causes a list of users to be fetched and added to assigneeList but not sure if opening the assignee dropdown is guaranteed to fix it, because, If there is a large number of users it only fetches a certain number of them for performance reasons.
fields.summary: Advanced Roadmap (JPO) throws "Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'jiraUsername' of undefined"

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When issues are related by issue link type "Relates to", Portfolio plan calls out the lead time as if the issues are link by link type BLOCKS.

 # Schedule any of these issue in portfolio plan. Let's say, MIG - 7
 # The lead time value for this issues MIG - 7 will have values as if it has to on wait MIG - 1 to complete.

h3. Expected Results

Both Jira issues MIG - 7 and MIG - 1 are allowed to start and finish independent of each other.
h3. Actual Results

PortFoliio treats "Relates to" issue link type as it treats issue link type "Blocks"
 !Screenshot 2020-09-16 at 1.53.35 PM.png|thumbnail!
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Lead time in Plan shows incorrect value when issues are linked by "Relates to" issue link type

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

If an issue in plan is set to a status in "Done" category, the same issue is removed from the plan by a user and the user tried to add the issue back to the plan, the plan does not display the completed issue in "Issue Source" configuration which prevents user from re-adding the issue to the plan.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Create a new Roadmap plan.
# Create an issue in the plan.
# Transition the issue to any of the completed status.
# Select the completed issue in the plan -> Click on bulk action -> Remove from plan. This will remove the issue from the plan.
# Access "Issue Source" configuration of the plan and navigate to Step 3 which will display all the issues which are available to the plan.
# Seach for the issue which was previously removed.


h3. Expected Results

The plan shows the completed issue in step 3 and user should be able to select it so Roadmap can display that issue in the plan.

h3. Actual Results

The completed issue will not be displayed in step 3 of the "Issue Source" configuration.

h3. Workaround

Transition the issue to a status which does not belong to "Done" category (any statuses in blue or grey colour). After transitoning the issue, edit the "Issue Source" of the plan and Roadmap should display the previously removed issue.
fields.summary: Unable to re-add completed issue to plan if the issue is removed from plan

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary
Whenever you create multiple Cross-project Releases (CPRs) that have the same name on different plans, and you connect these plans to a program when you try to filter information on the program by Release, you have no way of determining which CPR belongs to which plan.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create two different projects: First Project and Second Project.
# Create two different releases in each project. F1, F2 and S1, S2.
# Create two Advanced Roadmaps plans, use First project as an issue source for the first (Plan A), and Second Project as a source for the second (Plan B).
# Click on the *Releases tab* for the first plan (Plan A).
# Click on *Create releases* next to *Cross-Project Releases*.
# Include the F1 release from First Project and the S1 release from Second Project.
# Use *Name Test* as the release's name, and click on *Create Release*.
# Repeat steps 4. to 9. for the second plan (Plan B). 
# Create a program, by clicking on *Plans*, *Create* and selecting *Program*.
# Insert a *Name* for your new program and on *Connected plans* select *Plan A* and *Plan B*.
# The program will be created.
# On the scope section, you should be able to see the *Releases: All* filter, click on the dropdown menu. You should see two indistinguishable Cross-Project Releases named *Name Test*. 

h3. Expected Results
You should see some indication of the plan that was the source of the Cross-Project Release.

h3. Actual Results
There is no indication of this information as we can see in the screenshot below:
 
!Screen Shot 2020-09-10 at 01.11.10.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround

 Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available
fields.summary: Allow users to identify which plan is associated with a Cross-Project Release when filtering a program by release.

fields.description:

*Error*
 *This issue is missing some details that are specified in the issue sources of your plan. To make this issue visible, add these missing details to the issue.*

 

It would be useful if the message showed which is the missing details.
fields.summary: Improve message "This issue is missing some details that are specified in the issue sources of your plan. To make this issue visible, add these missing details to the issue." to show what is missing

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

In the new interface, there is a problem where no issues are scheduled by the auto-scheduler if there are 'Overlapping Active Sprints'. However, there is nothing to indicate what is wrong or if this is correct.

!image-2020-08-31-13-06-38-628.png!

The above warning is showing in the legacy interface during auto-scheduling, but not in the new interface.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Add overlapping Active Sprints that share the same Team as per: [Resolving conflicts in parallel sprints|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/resolving-conflicts-in-parallel-sprints-934719103.html]
 # Attempt to schedule the Plan from the new interface.

h3. Expected Results

Plan would schedule, or would alert end user to the issue with Overlapping Active Sprints in the new interface.
h3. Actual Results

Zero issues are scheduled and no warning is shown in the UI.
h3. Workaround

Schedule the Plan and resolve 'Overlapping active Sprints' while using the legacy interface.
fields.summary: Auto-Scheduling in the new interface while there are 'Overlapping Active Sprints' causes no issues to be scheduled, and no warning is presented to the user

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, Roadmap does not have a type of view where users can view the total progress in term of status category. Some users would like an automated user story progress calculation of estimated issues so they can track progress and provide estimated for management.


h3. Suggested Solution

Add a new view in Roadmap like what's shown below which shows the progress of all issues in term of status category

 !Screenshot 2020-08-31 at 10.22.12 PM.png|thumbnail! 

The calculation is based on user story 'Status' and 'Story points' estimate. Sum of Story points on User story:

* Done (Green) = Workflow status: 'Closed'
* In Progress (Yellow) = Workflow status: 'Resolved' 'Waiting' 'In progress'
* To Do estimated (blue) = Workflow status: 'Backlog' 'In refinement' 'Ready'
* To do unestimated (black) = Capability Estimate – Done – In progress – To do blue
IF<0 then = 0

Progress bar with (Unestimated - Black, Estimated - Blue, In Progress - Yellow and Done - Green

h3. Workaround 

None
fields.summary: New progress bar to keep track of status of issues

fields.description:
Transitioning a scrum issue spanning multiple sprints to Done status, makes is disappear from the last sprint in the Plan view

h3. Issue Summary
Transitioning a scrum issue spanning multiple sprints to Done status, makes is disappear from the last sprint in the Plan view
As long as the issue is still in the "ToDo" or "In Progress" status, everything is shown as expected in the Plan view.
The timeline spans the issues covering the timeframe of all involved sprints. 
The sprint overview in Portfolio also shows all sprints the issue was part of.

After closing the issue (transition it into a "Done" status) the latest (current) sprint does not appear as part of the issue anymore and the timeline doesn't cover the current sprint anymore. 
In addition, the capacity overview of the sprint shows, that less team capacity is used.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Install Jira and Advanced Roadmaps plugin
 # Create a scrum software project and create 1 Epic with multiple stories.
 # Create 2 sprints, and ensure 1 issue is not going to be finished in that sprint.
 # Create a plan based on the scrum project board.
 !screenshot_590.png|thumbnail! 
 # Ensure that 1 issue is moved from sprint 1 to sprint 2 after sprint 1 is finished.
 # Start sprint 2 and ensure that issue coming from sprint 1 is showing 2 sprints in the JPO Plan view.
 !screenshot_591.png|thumbnail! 
 # While sprint 2 is still running, transition the issue coming from sprint 1 to Done status.

h3. Expected Results
The issue coming from sprint 1 should continue to show 2 sprints in the JPO Plan view.

h3. Actual Results
The issue only shows Sprint 1 which is finished, Sprint 2 is not showing any more against that issue.
 !screenshot_592.png|thumbnail! 

*Notes:*
* Further more, the work done on the issue in sprint 2 doesn't reflect on the sprint timeline, thus it seems like the issue finished on sprint 1 which is not the case.
* Issue dependencies might get to broken for sprint 2.
* Capacity for sprint 2 is not shown correctly and could lead to the assumption the sprint is not fully planed.
* Grouping issues by sprint to report the outcome of a sprint to stakeholders might show the incorrect results.

h3. Workaround
No workaround is found for this issue issue at the moment.

*Note:*
* Once the last sprint is finished, the Plan view would show the issue again as part of the last sprint (sprint 2 in the above scenario), this is still not a workaround as the Plan view reporting is wrong during the last sprint runtime.
 !screenshot_593.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Transitioning a scrum issue spanning multiple sprints to Done status, makes is disappear from the last sprint in the Plan view

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

Incorrect text about the permissions of a restricted user inside the administration page of Advanced Roadmaps.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Go to the permissions administration page in Advanced Roadmaps.
h3. Expected Results

The text under permissions should state that restricted users _cannot_ make changes to Jira Software regardless of having the edit permission. The [Permissions in Portfolio for Jira|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jiraportfolioserver/permissions-in-portfolio-for-jira-934719058.html] state the information correctly:
{quote}However, even if restricted users are able to edit issue details in the plans, they cannot save these changes in Jira.
{quote}
h3. Actual Results

The permission for *Portfolio restricted user* states:
{quote}Can perform the same tasks as Portfolio user; however *restricted users can only save changes to Jira for the plans for which they have edit permissions*
{quote}
h3. Workaround

None, but the correct behaviour is that a restricted user should not be able to save any changes to Jira regardless of their permissions in Jira.
fields.summary: Permission pages shows incorrect behaviour for Restricted User

fields.description:
*Problem statement*

When user have a lot of dependences, some of the associated dependencies are off-screen  and cannot see all.
 - [Managing dependencies|https://confluence.atlassian.com/advancedroadmapsserver/managing-dependencies-960719448.html]

*Suggestion*

Add scroll for dependencies
fields.summary: Ability to add scroll bar to dependencies

fields.description:
When creating a new Plan based on a filter, Advanced Roadmaps for Jira uses the below REST API call to populate the list of available filters:
{code}
GET <JIRA_BASE_URL>/rest/jpo/1.0/filters
{code}
The call fetches only 50 filters and then populates these in the drop down list.
Upon typing more characters in the name of the filter, more calls are made to the above REST call using the parameter ?name=<typed_characters> until you are satisfied with the search results.
The limit of the above calls is still 5 filters per result from each call.
The problem would be if the user typed a part of a filter name and the results would be more than the 50 filters displayed, this, we would have matching filters that wouldn't be dispalyed.
If the user don'ts know the exact filter name, or if the user doesn't remember the name of the filter and it could happen that he can't find the filter as it is not displayed in the selection list.
This scenario is more likely on larger instances that contains a large amount of filters per user.

It might be better to allow Jira admin to configure the maximum value of retrieved filters, or to allow a button to use another call to bring in more results if more are found in the drop down list.
fields.summary: when creating plans, Allow the filter search results limit  to be configurable

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

The chart within a Plan utilizing the old interface is no longer showing the changes applied to capacity based on configured non-working days.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Within a Plan, create a non-working day within the date range of a current Sprint.
 # Calculate the Plan, and observe no change has been made to the Chart, but the 'Forecasted Velocity Chart' will show this correctly:

!image-2020-08-23-15-13-41-950.png|width=458,height=170!

In the above example, the Team has a 2 week velocity of 10 Points with 1 issue included in the Sprint that is estimated at 10 Story Points. This means with one Non-Working Day configured for this two week iteration, we should see Capacity lower than 10 for this Sprint.
h3. Expected Results

Value shown in Chart for Capacity would reduce based on Non-Working Days.
h3. Actual Results

After configuring a Non-Working day, these days are not calculated and shown in the Chart like the Forecasted Velocity Chart.
h3. Workaround

Downgrade to Advanced Roadmaps 3.20 or lower.

(!) Jira may need to be restarted for the Downgrade to take effect.
fields.summary: Configuring Non-Working Days in the Legacy Interface is not applied to Capacity in Chart

fields.description:
h3. Issue Summary

When committing changes, like a new issue, the interface doesn't give any means for the user to know why it failed.

While in the interface the very generic error "Could not be committed for unknown reasons" is thrown, the logs have the error.
h3. Steps to Reproduce

Example of trying to set an invalid assignee:
 # Set a project administrator as the default assignee
 # Set the project administrator user as inactive
 # Create an issue in Advanced Roadmaps
 # Attempt to commit the changes

h3. Expected Results

An error that the user can take action on.
h3. Actual Results

The user gets this error:
{panel:title=Could not be committed for unknown reasons.}
Item could not be committed for unknown reasons. Please contact your administrator.
{panel}
!portf error.png!

The below exception is thrown in the atlassian-jira.log file:
{noformat}
/rest/jpo/1.0/issues/commit [c.a.r.j.c.scenario.issue.IssueScenarioEntityCommitExceptionHandler] Exception when trying to commit issue: Specific error details: {assignee=The default assignee does NOT have ASSIGNABLE permission OR Unassigned issues are turned off.}.
{noformat}
h3. Workaround

Currently there is no known workaround for this behavior. A workaround will be added here when available.
fields.summary: When commiting an issue has an error, no details are shown on the interface

fields.description:
As a PM, I can select "Use Release dates" in the configuration for issue types when a sprint isn't provided without having to "auto-schedule"

As a PM, when I create my plan hierarchy of [Parent] -> Epic -> Story AND I set a release for those issues with a fixed end date, the Due Date [D] field AND I *have not* yet estimated, the timeline should forecast (the bar) to my fixed end date without having to "auto-schedule" SO THAT I can immediately see a representation of my epic on the timeline.

As a PM, when I create my plan hierarchy of [Parent] -> Epic -> Story AND I set a release for those issues with a fixed end date, the Due Date [D] field AND I *have not* yet estimated, the timeline should forecast (the bar) to my fixed end date So That I can immediately see a representation of my epic on the timeline more accurately reflected by the epic estimate.

As a PM, I'd like to be able to T-shirt size my epics and provide a template by which to map those sizes into projects (min -> max) on my timeline.  For example we use: S - 1-3 week, M - 3-6 weeks, L - 6-9 weeks.
fields.summary: Forcast roadmap based on release dates and estimates provided, not just start and end date.
